#â€‹716 â€” December 12, 2024

Read on the Web

JavaScript Weekly

Boa v0.20: An Alternative JavaScript Compiler â€” Under development for several years, Boa has a few missions: be a Rust ECMAScript implementation, be easy to embed in Rust projects, and be a fast, safe JS engine overall. v0.20 sees a bump up to 89.92% compliance in the Test262 suite, improves Temporal support, adds Atomics.pause, and more. This is no toyÂ engine.

Boa Developers

React v19 Now Stable â€” First teased in a February 2024 update, React 19 has been in beta for 8 months, so thereâ€™s already a wealth of content about it, from the React 19 upgrade guide or an explanation of its compiler to cheat sheets and Vercelâ€™s roundup of whatâ€™s new in ReactÂ 19.

The React Team

Build with Gemini at Lightning Speeds â€” With the largest context window available, Google Gemini provides JavaScript developers multimodal processing of images, videos and text. Start using Google Gemini in minutes using AIÂ Studio.

Google Gemini sponsor

IN BRIEF:

  • ğŸ® If you ever do any game development with JavaScript, it's time to take the Gamedev.JS Survey 2024. If you don't, you can head to JS13KGames and enjoy other people's creative efforts insteadÂ :-)

  • Apple has released Safari 18.2 which introduces a few enhancements to JavaScript support including Float16Array, more methods for Uint8Array, Promise.try, RegExp.escape, and more.

  • Did you know Douglas Crockford is Not Your Dad? Well, at least when it comes to putting comments in JSON..

RELEASES:

  • VS Code November Release â€“ Now when you copy and paste JS/TS code, VS Code can add imports for the pasted code.

  • Next.js 15.1 â€“ The popular React framework gets full React 19Â support.

  • Node v23.4.0 (Current) â€“ Say hello to assert.partialDeepStrictEqual and --trace-env for tracing environment variableÂ usage.

  • Sheriff v25 - Opinionated TypeScript-first ESLint configuration. Now supporting ESLintÂ v9.

  • Undici 7.1 â€“ HTTP/2 support now marked as stable in the Node.js HTTPÂ library.

  • pnpm 9.15, Dependency Cruiser 16.8, Redux Toolkit 2.5, YouTube.js 12.2

ğŸ“’Â Articles & Tutorials

The State of Node.js Performance in 2024 â€” A thorough set of benchmarks covering recent performance advancements made in Node.js. The improvements between Node 18 and 20 up to version 22 might surprise you - itâ€™s clear the team has put a lot of work into thisÂ area.

Gonzaga and Parody (NodeSource)

How to Reduce TTFB? â€” High "time to first byte" affects web vitals. Learn to identify and fix issues slowing yourÂ TTFB.

Sentry sponsor

Publishing a Simple Client-Side JS Package to npm with GitHubÂ Actions â€” As part of the process of building Prompts.js, a new library for creating simple await-able alternatives to alert(), confirm() and prompt(), Simon wanted to make it easy to publish as an npm packageÂ too.

Simon Willison

How to Build a SolidJS App with Deno â€” SolidJS is a declarative library for creating user interfaces that emphasizes fine-grained reactivity and minimal overhead and it plays well withÂ Deno.

Andy Jiang

Get Cooking! Generative AI with MongoDB â€” See how MongoDB, the worldâ€™s most popular document database, integrates with RAG pipelines and cutting-edge AIÂ agents.

MongoDB sponsor

ğŸ“„ Building Your Own npm create Package â€“ You'll have seen (or used) various scaffolding tools using this technique. (A Different) Alex Chan

ğŸ“„ What We Learned Migrating From Webpack to Vite Roman Zaynetdinov

ğŸ“„ Understanding the Browser's Main Thread Amrik Malhans

ğŸ“º An Honest Review of TanStack Start vs Next.js Ankita Kulkarni

ğŸ“„ How React Compiler Performs on Real Code Nadia Makarevich

ğŸ› Â Code & Tools

Termo: An Easy to Use Terminal Control for Websites â€” If you want to offer a terminal emulator style feature on your site (maybe for advanced users, to enhance your docs, or even just as an easter egg), Termo enhances Xterm.js and presents a slickÂ experience.

Raj Nandan Sharma

ğŸ–¼ï¸Â wasm-vips: libvips Image Processing via WebAssembly â€” libvips is an efficient image processing library written in C. This build offers an isomorphic route to using it in the browser, as well as Node and Deno, all thanks to WebAssembly. (There's an interactive demoÂ here.)

Kleis Auke Wolthuizen

Looking for a DIY Survey Solution? SurveyJS Has You Covered â€” Build, customize, and store surveys with ease. Total data control, JSON-driven, no backend restrictionsâ€”integrates into any JavaScriptÂ app.

SurveyJS sponsor

Civet 0.9: Code More with Less Using a TypeScript Superset â€” Two years old and well maintained, Civet offers an interesting approach. Think JavaScript but with Python style indentation, chained comparisons, built-in JSX, & more. This example alone shows off the potential for tighter, easier-to-writeÂ code.

Daniel X Moore and Contributors

Rockpack 5.0: An Alternative React App Starter â€” A Create React App-style tool aiming to get React project setup time as low as possible, complete with server side rendering support, bundling, linting and testing. GitHubÂ repo.

Alex Sergey

jsesc: Get a Stringified, ASCII-Safe Representation of Any Data â€” Think JSON.stringify() but instead it returns JavaScript meaning it can support things like maps, sets, and BigInts.

Mathias Bynens

  • ğŸ“Š Perspective 3.2 (above) â€“ Data visualization and analytics component. The core is written in C++ and compiled to WebAssembly where it can be used fromÂ JavaScript. Their homepage shows it off well with a live example. Now supports newline delimited JSONÂ (ndjson).

  • â˜ï¸ International Telephone Input 25.2 â€“ Component for entering and validating international phoneÂ numbers. Vue, React, andÂ vanilla.

  • debug 4.4 â€“ Tiny debugging utility modelled after Node.js core's debuggingÂ approach (but for the browserÂ too).

  • ExpressoTS 3.0 â€“ TypeScript framework for server-side Node.jsÂ apps.

  • InversifyJS 6.2 â€“ Inversion of control container forÂ JavaScript.

  • ğŸ“Š ApexCharts 4.2 â€“ Popular JS charting library. (Demos.)

  • Vue3-Carousel 0.9 â€“ Customizable, lightweight Vue 3 carousel component.

  • html-react-parser 5.2 â€“ Isomorphic HTML to ReactÂ parser.

  • AlaSQL.js 4.6 â€“ Isomorphic JavaScript SQLÂ database.

ğŸ“°Â Classifieds

Meticulous automatically creates & maintains E2E UI tests. Zero flakes. Used by Lattice, Bilt Rewards andÂ others.

If your work leans more towards the frontend, be sure to check out the latest issue of Frontend Focus, our sister newsletter focused on all thingsÂ browser-side.

item.title: ã€A 2024 JavaScript retrospectiveã€‘2024 å¹´ JavaScript å›é¡¾
item.description:
ã€

#â€‹717 â€” December 19, 2024

Read on the Web

ğŸ„ We've made it to the end of 2024! In this issue, we're being reflective, leading with a few news items but then looking at what made 2024 special in the world of JavaScript, and covering some of the biggest things we linked to this year.

Then we're on a Christmas break for two weeks and will be back in your inbox on Friday, January 10, 2025, â€” yes, we're moving back to Fridays for 2025!Â We hope you have a Merry Christmas and a Happy New Year.
__
Peter Cooper and the Cooperpress team

JavaScript Weekly

The State of JavaScript 2024 Results â€” We recently encouraged you to take the annual State of JavaScript survey; the results are now out. 14,015 folks took part and we get to see what language features folks are using, experiences with popular libraries, build tool popularity, AI preferences, popular podcasts, runtime usage, and perhaps controversially, how more JavaScript developers are using TypeScript than not. Thereâ€™s a lot to dig throughÂ here.

Sacha Greif

Complete Intro to React v9: New Project, ModernÂ Stack â€” Join Brian Holt in building a pizza delivery app from scratch. Master hooks, TanStack Router, testing, and React 19 features in this comprehensive guide to modern React development. No prior React experienceÂ needed.

Frontend Masters sponsor

IN BRIEF:

  • ğŸ¥‡ JetBrains' recent State of Developer Ecosystem report shows that JavaScript is "the most used programming language", reports InfoWorld's Paul Krill. The report also claims "despite its gains, TypeScript will not replaceÂ JavaScript".

ğŸ—“ï¸Â What Happened to JavaScript in 2024

The JavaScript world has had a busy 2024, as you'd expect for the world's most used programming language (despite the threat of being split into two). We looked back over the year and remembered some things that occurred:

  • In February, the React team posted a mega 'React Labs' update which framed the whole of React's year, explaining the goals of the React Compiler and the eventual React 19 release (which went stable this month).

  • Alternative JavaScript runtimes had a great 2024, particularly Bun which introduced Bun Shell, Windows support and the ability to compile and run native C from JavaScript. Deno had a big year too, with the release of Deno 2 which included stronger Node.js/npm compatibility and package management tooling. Other systems continuing to progress this year include Boa JS, QuickJS, and Porffor.

  • Over at TC39, lots of language proposals were advanced this year (and that's just a sample â€“ here's some more!). The ES2025 future is bright.

Boost Semantic Search with MongoDB Atlas Vector Search â€” Create embeddings, index them, and run semantic queriesâ€”just follow the quick startÂ tutorial.

MongoDB sponsor

  • Deno decided to take the JavaScript trademark fight to Oracle and formally filed a petition with the USPTO to cancel it. We hope to see some developments here in 2025, but Oracle are prepared to defendÂ it.

  • Not content to merely work on an edge platform, JS runtime, and fight Oracle, Deno also unveiled JSR, a fresh attempt at providing a registry for JavaScriptÂ packages.

  • There were lots of big releases generally for major JavaScript projects including Svelte v5, Node.js v23.0, Astro 5.0, TypeScript 5.7, Vite 6.0, React Native 0.76, Next.js 15, React Router v7, Rspack 1.0, Vue.js 3.5, and Angular 19.

  • The OG of JavaScript libraries jQuery 4.0 went into beta too! We keep our fingers crossed for a jQuery 4.0 final release in 2025..Â ;-)

ğŸ¥‡Â Our Top Items of 2024

Next up is a walk through the top items we included in 2024, ordered by level of reader engagement. No editorial judgments here â€“ these are the things you cared about most:

1.Â console.delight â€” By far our most popular link of the year with over 20,000 clicks(!) â€“ but who doesn't use and love console.log? This post showed us how in the browser console it's not merely for printing plain text, but can be used to render things like SVGs and HTML.

Zach Saucier

2.Â JavaScript Visualized: Promise Execution â€” A well-diagrammed article coupled with an (optional) 8 minute video that went into how promises work under the hood. Hugely popular as most of Lydia's content tends toÂ be.

Lydia Hallie

WorkOS: Sell to Enterprises with a Few Lines of Code â€” The modern identity platform for B2B SaaS, offering flexible, easy-to-use APIs to integrate SSO, SCIM, and FGA in minutes instead ofÂ months.

WorkOS sponsor

3.Â Is htmx Just Another JavaScript Framework? â€” Despite being five years old, htmx has seen a surge in popularity in 2023 and 2024, partly due to framework fatigue, but also as its simple HTML-oriented approach to adding functionality to pages appeals to a diverse group of developers. v2.0 landed in June.

Alexander Petros

4.Â Ecma International Approves ECMAScript 2024: Whatâ€™s New? â€” In June, the Ecma General Assembly approved the latest ECMAScript / JavaScript spec, officially making it a standard. As with ES2023, it was a reasonably small step forward, but Dr. Axel rounded up what wasÂ new.

Dr. Axel Rauschmayer

5.Â JavaScript's ??= Operator: Default Values Made Simple â€” The ??= nullish coalescing assignment operator snuck into JavaScript a few years ago via ES2021 and has been broadly supported almost everywhere for ages. Trevor showed off how it can tighten up yourÂ assignments.

Trevor I. Lasn

6.Â Eloquent JavaScript: The Fourth Edition â€” Coming several years after the third edition, the latest version of what is, perhaps, the best â€˜all rounderâ€™ book for learning JavaScript arrived in March â€œadjusted to the realities of 2024 and generally touchedÂ up.â€

Marijn Haverbeke

7.Â 33 JavaScript Concepts Every Developer Should Know â€” A curated collection of links to tutorials on 33 different areas itâ€™s worth understanding well, including types, closures, equality, scope, and differentÂ engines.

Leonardo Maldonado

8.Â How Google Handles JavaScript In Its Indexing Process â€” At one point if you wanted Google to index your content it needed to be directly written in HTML and not dynamically rendered with JavaScript. Things have since changed, of course, but by howÂ much?

Zecchini, Moore, Siddle, Ubl (Vercel)

item.title: ã€Oracle engages its lawyers and JavaScript turns 29ã€‘Oracle è˜è¯·å¾‹å¸ˆï¼ŒJavaScript å·²æ»¡ 29 å²
item.description:
ã€

#â€‹715 â€” December 5, 2024

Read on the Web

ğŸ—“ï¸ If you missed last week's issue, don't worry, it didn't exist â€“ we took a week off for Thanksgiving! We're now back all the way through to the Christmas break :-)
__
Your editor, Peter Cooper

JavaScriptâ„¢ Weekly

Deno v. Oracle: Cancelling the JavaScript Trademark â€” Did you know Oracle formally owns the â€˜JavaScriptâ€™ trademark? There have been a few efforts to change this over the years but Oracle isnâ€™t listening, so the Deno team formally filed a petition to cancel the trademark.

Deno

âš–ï¸ And, as of this week, it looks like Oracle is lawyering up to defend it [PDF].

ğŸ‚Â JavaScript Turns 29 Years Old â€” If youâ€™re wondering why Oracle has the JavaScript trademark, it's because Sun owned the name and Oracle acquired Sun (which is also why it owns Java). As someone who was posting inane questions in comp.lang.javascript in 1996, this news makes me feel old â€“ no-one could have anticipated what JavaScript would beÂ today.

Netscape and Sun Microsystems

Add Excel-like Spreadsheet Functionality to Your JavaScript Apps â€” SpreadJS is the industry-leading JavaScript spreadsheet for adding advanced spreadsheet features to your enterprise apps. Build finance, analysis, budget, and other apps. Excel I/O, 500+ calc functions, tables, charts, and more. View demosÂ now.

SpreadJS from MESCIUS inc sponsor

Astro 5.0: The Web Framework for Content-Driven Sites â€” Astro has taken the front-end world by storm and v5.0 keeps up its rapid pace of development. Content Layer makes it easy to load content from any source and Server Islands can combine cached, static content with dynamic content. Thereâ€™s now a type-safe way to manage environment variables and Vite 6 is along for the ride too. You can play with Astro 5 using the astro.new site.

The Astro Team

Take the State of JavaScript 2024 Survey â€” Each year, Devographics runs a popular survey to see what JS features and tools you know about, use, and love/hate. Itâ€™s structured such that you can learn something just from taking it and the results are always interesting (see 2023â€™s). Itâ€™s open for a few more days, despite what the pageÂ says. (Or â–¶ï¸ watch someone else takingÂ it?)

Devographics

IN BRIEF:

  • npmjs.com has a 'new, streamlined search experience. It's mostly a tweaking of the 'sort' options â€“ so take a search like this one for 'svg', you can now sort by recent download counts and dependencyÂ levels.

  • TC39 News: Import Sync (explained here) is being promoted to stage 1, Error.isError moves to stage 3, and Intl.DurationFormat moves to stage 4.

  • ğŸ„ Adrian Roselli has a roundup of development-themed advent calendars for you to enjoy this month, including Advent of TypeScript. 'Tis theÂ season!

  • Porffor is an interesting ahead-of-time JavaScript compiler, now complete with a snazzy newÂ homepage.

  • test262.fyi presents a technical view of how different JS engines fare on the official ECMAScript conformanceÂ suite.

RELEASES:

  • TypeScript 5.7 â€“ The final release of the typed JavaScriptÂ superset.

  • Node.js v22.12.0 (LTS) â€“ A noteworthy release as it's the first Node LTS release with require(esm) enabled byÂ default.

  • Radon IDE 1.0 â€“ Turn VS Code or Cursor into a fully-fledged React NativeÂ IDE.

  • Prisma 6 â€“ Powerful Node.js + TypeScript ORM.

  • Vite 6.0, React Router 7.0, Undici 7, ESLint v9.16.0, Meteor.js 3.1, Relay 18.2, Tailwind CSS v4.0 Beta, Redux Toolkit 2.4, Bun 1.1.38, NeutralinoJS 5.5

ğŸ“’Â Articles & Tutorials

ğŸ¤–Â Using Transformers.js for AI in the Browser â€” Transformers.js is a seriously impressive project we link from time to time that lets you run pretrained machine learning models in the browser. Hereâ€™s a practical look at actually playing with it yourself rightÂ now.

Raymond Camden

Working with JavaScript's Scheduler API â€” A look at an API only available in Chromium/Edge for now, but that promises a way to prioritize and control task execution in a more refined way than was possible tillÂ now.

Trevor I. Lasn

Quokka V2: Deeper Code Insights & Interactive Timeline with New UI â€” The #1 JavaScript scratchpad just got better! Quokka v2 brings a new UI, interactive timeline, and tools for fasterÂ prototyping.

Wallaby Team sponsor

ğŸ“‰Â How To Improve 'Interaction to Next Paint' in React Apps â€” Interaction to Next Paint (INP) is a Web performance metric based on the responsiveness of an app to user interactions â€“ Google uses it as part of its ranking mechanism. Jacob offers up advice and resources for improving your INP scores in ReactÂ apps.

Jacob 'Kurt' GroÃŸ

How Airtable Scaled TypeScript to Thousands of Projects â€” â€œToday we have nearly 3000 TypeScript projects. Thatâ€™s why weâ€™re sharing our journey to so many projects, and how it reduced our typechecking time byÂ 65%.â€

Michael Mitchell (Airtable)

â–¶Â Â Building a Teleprompter App in 30 Minutes with AI â€” Building apps with AI powered tools isnâ€™t unusual nowadays, but if youâ€™ve never been through the process, this is a good look at how it works all the way through toÂ deployment.

Kilian Ekamp

Build Fully Functional Apps in Minutes, Not Months â€” Create, run, edit, and deploy full-stack web apps withÂ Bolt.

StackBlitz sponsor

ğŸ“º Four Talks from the London TypeScript Meetup â€“ All top notch talks. Bloomberg

ğŸ“„ Optimize JS Module Loading with link rel='modulepreload' Trevor I. Lasn

ğŸ“„ Running Your Next.js SSR App on Deno Deploy Orriols and Jiang (Deno)

ğŸ“„ From Jekyll to Astro: An AI-Assisted Migration Kevin London

ğŸ› Â Code & Tools

Linkify 4.2: Link Up URLs, Emails, and More in Plain Text â€” Given plain text containing things like links, hashtags, IP addresses, and email addresses, this will generate the correct code to display it on the Web. GitHubÂ repo.

Hypercontext

Skia Canvas 2.0: A 'Browserless' Canvas Environment for Node.js â€” Based on Googleâ€™s Skia engine and offers end results similar to Chromeâ€™s own canvas system. GPU accelerated and can render images, paths, fonts, shapes, etc. v2.0 adds support for WOFF/WOFF2 fonts, WEBP, and more. GitHubÂ repo.

Christian Swinehart

Introducing <Waitlist/> Mode - A Virtual Queue for Your App â€” Launching a new product but not ready to open it up to everyone yet? Waitlist Sign-up mode is yourÂ solution.

Clerk sponsor

Math.js 14.0: An Extensive Math Library â€” Work with complex numbers, fractions, units, matrices, symbolic computation, etc. A long standing library continuing to get frequent updates. GitHubÂ repo.

Jos de Jong

Onlook: 'Figma'-Like Design App for React â€” A new open source, local-first design app (for Windows, Linux & macOS) targeting React apps. Design layouts directly on a live page and instantly write your changes to code. GitHubÂ repo.

On Off Inc.

ğŸ•’Â SpaceTime 7.7: A Lightweight Timezone Library â€” Use this to calculate times in other timezones. Has a Moment-like API but is immutable. No dependencies. Now updated for 2025. GitHubÂ repo.

Spencer Kelly

BunBuster: A Fast Web and TCP Fuzzer for Brute Forcing Servers â€” As always, use these sorts of things in a responsible way, but itâ€™s interesting to see tools like this now being built in JavaScript, thanks to Bunâ€™s speed and ease of distributingÂ binaries.

Tiago Rangel

Kaluma: A Tiny JS Runtime for the Raspberry Pi Pico â€” Can a JS runtime squeeze into 64KB to run on the RP2040-based Raspberry Pi Pico? Kaluma can, even while offering Node.js-styleÂ niceties.

Kaluma Project

Todoctor: A Tool to Analyze and Track TODO Comments â€” A CLI tool designed to collect and monitor TODO/FIXME-style comments in JavaScript and TypeScriptÂ projects. GitHub repo.

Azat S

ğŸ“°Â Classifieds

ğŸª Hookdeck: A serverless queue to reliably send, receive, transform, filter, and route events across your event-drivenÂ apps.

Meticulous automatically creates & maintains E2E UI tests. Zero flakes. Used by Lattice, Bilt Rewards andÂ others.

  • ğŸ PythonMonkey 1.1 â€“ Embed the SpiderMonkey JS engine into Python'sÂ VM.

  • nrm 1.5 â€“ Fast switching between registries: npm, cnpm, nj,Â taobao.

  • LogTape 0.8 â€“ Simple logging library for all major JSÂ runtimes.

  • Faker 9.3 â€“ Generate fabricated data to your heart'sÂ content.

  • np 10.1 â€“ A better npmÂ publish. Now supports BunÂ too.

  • DOCX 9.1 â€“ Generate .docx / WordÂ files fromÂ JavaScript.

  • Preact 10.25 â€“ The 3KB React-compatibleÂ alternative.

#â€‹718 â€” January 10, 2025

Read on the Web

ğŸ—“ï¸ Friday is the new Thursday! If you were a JavaScript Weekly reader several years ago, you might remember it always landed on Fridays and after getting caught out by a variety of big news items landing on Thursdays in recent years, we're backÂ ;-)
__
Your editor, Peter Cooper

JavaScript Weekly

â­Â 2024's JavaScript Rising Stars â€” Itâ€™s time to fully wave goodbye to 2024, but not before Michael Rambeauâ€™s annual analysis of which JavaScript projects fared best on GitHub over the past year. Even if you dislike GitHub stars as a metric for anything, this remains a great way to get a feel for the JavaScript ecosystem and see what libraries and tools have mindshare in a variety of niches. A fantastic roundup asÂ always.

Michael Rambeau

A Look at Import Attributes â€” Itâ€™s always a pleasure to see Dr. Axel blogging about JavaScript again, and heâ€™s back with one of his typical deep dives into a newer ECMAScript feature: import attributes. This feature provides an inline syntax for attaching metadata to module imports such as for importing non-JavaScript modules (e.g. JSON, WASM orÂ CSS).

Dr. Axel Rauschmayer

How to Enable End-to-End Testing with Synthetic Monitoring â€” Synthetic Monitoring helps you launch new features with confidence and speed. Learn how you can create robust end-to-end test suites, spend less time on false positives, and proactively catch errors before they get toÂ production.

Datadog sponsor

Nodeâ€™s New Built-in Support for TypeScript â€” Node.js v23.6.0 (Current) has just been released and makes Nodeâ€™s new type-stripping features work by default, so you can just run node file.ts and it Should Just Workâ„¢. Dr. Axel explains how it works and what the limitationsÂ are.

Dr. Axel Rauschmayer

IN BRIEF:

  • ğŸ¥Š The Deno vs Oracle fight over the JavaScriptâ„¢ trademark continues as Oracle has informed Deno they're not going to voluntarily relinquish the mark. Deno's job now is to show how JavaScript has long been used as a generic term and hasn't been controlled by Oracle.

  • The Express.js team has posted about the project's recent revival and its plans to push Express.js forward inÂ 2025.

  • â„ï¸ The 'WinterCG' Web Interoperable Runtimes Community Group, an effort to promote standards around runtime interoperability of JavaScript runtimes, has moved to Ecma International and is now known as WinterTC (TC55).

  • ğŸ“º Node.js creator Ryan Dahl gave a talk at GOTO Chicago 2024 about Deno 2, covering Deno's differences to Node and what Deno 2.0 (and JSR) has to offer JavaScript developers, complete with liveÂ demos.

RELEASES:

  • pnpm 10 â€“ The efficient npm alternative no longer runs lifecycle scripts of dependencies for security reasons, hashing algorithms have been upgraded to SHA256, and lots of minorÂ tweaks.

  • Bun v1.1.43 â€“ The high-performance runtime gets first class S3 support, an HTML bundler, and can output V8 heap snapshots (which is quite something as Bun uses JavaScriptCore, notÂ V8).

  • ğŸ”  Tesseract.js 6.0 â€“ The popular pure JS multilingual OCR library has resolved a variety of memory leakÂ issues.

  • Docusaurus 3.7 â€“ The popular docs-oriented site generator goes full React 19.

  • Node.js v22.13.0 (LTS) â€“ The permission model system is nowÂ stable.

  • Puppeteer 24.0, RxDB 16.0, Ember 6.1, QuickJS 0.8

ğŸ“’Â Articles & Tutorials

The Future of htmx â€” htmx is an increasingly popular way to enhance HTML and actually write less JavaScript on the frontend. This post reflects on how htmx would like to be â€˜the new jQueryâ€™, not least in the sense that one of the projectâ€™s goals is to push the ideas of htmx into the HTML standard itself, as in this set ofÂ proposals.

Gross and Petros

You Don't Need Next.js â€” As much as Next.js is considered the React meta-framework of choice, if your requirements are modest, simply going with plain React offers numerous benefits in terms of simplicity and speed, as seenÂ here.

Benny Kok

Introducing Clerk SDKs for Vue and Nuxt â€” Official @clerk/vue & @clerk/nuxt SDKs for authentication integration with pre-built UI components in Vue/Nuxt apps.

Clerk sponsor

Using TypeScript Without Build Tools â€” Chris Coyier enjoys the benefits of TypeScript while developing, but actually compiling it to JavaScript in various scenarios is less endearing. Weâ€™ve learnt (above) that Node can now run .ts files directly, but what other projects support the use of TypeScript without buildÂ tools?

Chris Coyier

ğŸ“„ Using a JavaScript Component Inside a Haskell App â€“ Did you know Haskellâ€™s main compiler supports integrating withÂ JavaScript? Mateusz GoÅ›linowski

ğŸ“„ Crafting a Dreamy Particle Effect with Three.js and GPGPU Dominik Fojcik

ğŸ“„ Build Your Own Site Speed Testing Tool with Puppeteer Henry Price

ğŸ“„ Sharing a Variable Across HTML, CSS, and JavaScript Chris Coyier

ğŸ“„ Benchmarking GraphQL Solutions in the JS/TS Landscape Tomasz NieÅ¼urawski

ğŸ“„ Shallow Clones vs Structured Clones Phil Nash

ğŸ› Â Code & Tools

PostalMime: A Universal Email Parsing Library â€” An email parsing library happy in most JS runtimes. Takes the raw source of emails and parses them into their constituentÂ parts.

Postal Systems

trimMiddle(): The Missing String Trim Method? â€” If youâ€™ve got a long string and want to keep the start and end and truncate in the middle, this is for you. Thereâ€™s a live demo here and GitHubÂ repo.

Christian Heilmann

Fully Customizable Form Builder that Blends Seamlessly with Your JSÂ App â€” Need a survey solution you control? With SurveyJS, customize your form builderâ€™s look and functionality. Try it forÂ free.

SurveyJS sponsor

Introducing @smoores/epub: A Package for Working with EPUB Files â€” EPUB is a popular e-book file format and this new library provides a way to both read and write them. npm packageÂ link.

Shane Friedman

Tipex: An Advanced Rich Text Editor for Svelte â€” Based on the popular Tiptap editor framework, itâ€™s customizable, has theming support, and is Svelte 5-ready. Hereâ€™s a liveÂ example.

Friend of Svelte

React-Toastify 11: In-Page Notifications Made Easy â€” Thereâ€™s an elaborate demo page here but essentially itâ€™s a flexible, easy to style â€˜toastâ€™ style notifications system with many years under its belt. GitHubÂ repo.

Fadi Khadra

Electrobun: A New JS Cross-Platform Desktop App Toolkit â€” A fresh take on the concept covered by Electron and Neutralinojs, except based around Bun. Itâ€™s early days, though, with only ARM-based Macs supported forÂ now.

Blackboard Technologies inc.

Tagify 4.33: An Elegant Input Component for Tags â€” The polished demos show a lot of effort has been put in here. GitHubÂ repo.

Yair Even-Or

  • ğŸ“Š Recharts v2.15.0 â€“ D3-powered React chart library now with React 19Â support.

  • Discordeno 21.0 â€“ Discord API library for Node, Deno andÂ Bun.

  • htmlparser2 10.0 â€“ Fast and forgiving HTML and XMLÂ parser.

  • Ts.ED 8.4 â€“ Node + TypeScript framework on top ofÂ Express.

  • ğŸ“Š ApexCharts 4.3 â€“ Popular JS charting library.Â (Demos.)

  • zx 8.3 â€“ Google's tool for better Node.js shellÂ scripting.

  • Octokit.js 4.1 â€“ 'Batteries-included' GitHubÂ SDK.

ğŸ“°Â Classifieds

Meticulous automatically creates and maintains an E2E UI test suite with zero developer effort. Relied on by Lattice, Bilt Rewards,Â etc.

ğŸ”¹Sell to enterprise with a few lines of code with WorkOS â€” the modern, flexible identity platform for B2B SaaS. Integrate SSO, SCIM and FGA in minutes, notÂ months.

ğŸÂ And one for fun?

ğŸ“„Â Play Tetris in a PDF File â€” (direct link to PDF)

I'll let you decide if this one is fun or frightening! Whether or not this will work depends on your PDF reader or browser support, but it works with Chrome and Firefox, atÂ least.

The PDF document format supports embedded JavaScript and this experiment uses it to implement a game of Tetris. The developer, Thomas Rinsma, has used Python to output the PostScript that includes the game's JavaScript. Couple that with the fact many browser PDF renderers are themselves implemented in JavaScript (e.g. PDF.js) and you have a veritable Matryoshka doll of technologies at playÂ here.
